record.text: I obviously would never defend a corporation or anything but the thing about American Capitalism is that even if a company *wants* to lower prices, it often *can't* because of competition, fiduciary duty, &c. It's often better for them if we just make a law that forces their hand!

value.text:

"it was not a significant bullet" this absolute motherfucker

value.text: Oh my god

images.alt: Among the more memorable pieces of film Herzog has been involved in demonstrates this blasé attitude toward peril. The clip, “Werner Herzog is SHOT during interview,” is on YouTube, and if you haven’t seen it, I cannot recommend it highly enough. During a BBC interview, conducted outdoors in the Hollywood hills with the film critic Mark Kermode, Herzog is interrupted by a loud noise. It soon becomes clear that he has been shot in the stomach by a lunatic with a gun on a nearby veranda. Kermode is aghast, and insists that they stop the

interview so that Herzog can get help, but Herzog is dismissive. The bullet has penetrated his leather jacket, but the wound itself is nothing to speak of. “It was not a significant bullet,” he says. In a subsequent interview, published in the book Werner Herzog: A Guide for the Perplexed (2014), he made it clear that he was still angry about the incident—not at the man who shot him, but at the TV crew for making such a fuss about it. “I would have continued with the interview,” he said, “but the cameraman had already hit the dirt. The miserable, cowardly BBC crew were terrified and wanted to call the cops, but I had no interest in spending the next five hours filling out police reports.”

Among the more memorable pieces of film Herzog has been involved in demonstrates this blasé attitude toward peril. The clip, “Werner Herzog is SHOT during interview,” is on YouTube, and if you haven’t seen it, I cannot recommend it highly enough. interview so that Herzog can get help, but Herzog is dismissive. The bullet has penetrated his leather jacket, but the wound itself is nothing to speak of. “It was not a significant bullet,” he says. In a subsequent interview, published in the book Werner Herzog: A Guide for the Perplexed (2014), he made it clear that he was still angry about the incident—not at the man who shot him, but at the TV crew for making such a fuss about it. “I would have continued with the interview,” he said, “but the cameraman had already hit the dirt. The miserable, cowardly BBC crew were terrified and wanted to call the cops, but I had no interest in spending the next five hours filling out police reports.”

This is intuitively true to me, and I'd go even further and suggest that, since people mostly believe things because of peer influence, reason is maybe even less about individual persuasion and more about sorting out which people are on what side of the argument.

record.text: One of the better books I read this year is "The Enigma of Reason," in which the authors argued that Reason did not evolve as a problem solving skill (which psychology and neuroscience have shown it's very bad at) but as a social skill for persuading other people to your point of view.
Like all people, *sometimes* what you want is for people to understand what you think or believe, but *every* time you use words you're using them to get something that you want.

The real thing to understand is that, for the most part, people don't use words to *convey what they mean*, they use words to *get what they want*. There's no coherent rational principle ideology behind ideas like "free speech" or "cancel culture"

value.text: /2 . . . how a huge segment of the  “free speech activist” culture is just absolutely pathologically oversensitive to criticism and dissent and how much of the “we hate cancel culture” culture is consumed with telling people to shut up.

record.text: That's a revelation. Turns out I've been doing it all wrong.

"Elon Musk *claims* to believe that a free speech market will self regulate, and insists that this is what he's made on Twitter" is the statement that's actually *technically accurate*. Whether Musk really believes that is not observable and saying it is therefore opinion!

The thing about this is that "Elon Musk believes that a market for free speech will self-regulate" is bad reporting even by the bloodless view-from-nowhere standard of the NYT. How many times have we heard that we can't call someone, i.e., "racist", because we don't know what they really *believe*?

value.text: If you uncritically think Elon Musk is against censorship, you are too stupid to be in journalism or opining on current events. One of the first things he did after acquiring Twitter was to outright ban left wing journalists and journalists critical of him.

record.text: Cynical take I will probably regret: when it comes to words, what most people want is to use them to make themselves feel better about themselves by shitting on others.

Like on the internet, "winning an argument" isn't really about being right per se, it's about a performance of the interlocutor as "unlisten-to-able", right? The point isn't to get to some mutually-compatible version of reality, it's to demonstrate why you don't have to take the other guy seriously.

The real thing to understand is that, for the most part, people don't use words to *convey what they mean*, they use words to *get what they want*. There's no coherent rational principle ideology behind ideas like "free speech" or "cancel culture"

record.text: No, You’re Not Having a Stroke.  Everything Really is This Fucking Stupid

Sure, but that's not really the argument that's on the table. Instead of talking about the problem that we're facing right now, someone wants to talk about the problem we'll face after the problem we're facing -- a lot of people are going to see that as a deliberate distraction.

I like Aaron but this feels like a cop-out. Literally every political issue involves history and nuance that we as civilians can't fully understand. 

It's an especially bad framework to apply to Gaza, which by this point could not be simpler: It is wrong to kill civilians for months on end.
yes, I agree. I am arguing that **after the bombing stops,** there will be many complicated questions to solve

That things are complicated is true, but trivial. The life of a human being that leads to him trying to shoot me and steal my wallet is undoubtedly complex and full of nuance and various exigencies; he still shouldn't do that.

I like Aaron but this feels like a cop-out. Literally every political issue involves history and nuance that we as civilians can't fully understand. 

It's an especially bad framework to apply to Gaza, which by this point could not be simpler: It is wrong to kill civilians for months on end.
that's precisely what I'm saying! Of course it's complicated; everything is. Apartheid also had a long, complex history but it wasn't necessary for civilians to know it in detail before opposing it.
I mean, a thing can be a complex situation with lots of historical nuance but also have an immediate upshot of "Israel should stop bombing civilians and starving their children to death"

my view on the Israel-Palestine conflict is that it’s been going on for more than a century & there are shades of gray on both sides. It’s not a simple story of good vs evil. This may sound obvious but acknowledging complexity too often gets you tarred as a heinous person.

my view on the Israel-Palestine conflict is that it’s been going on for more than a century & there are shades of gray on both sides. It’s not a simple story of good vs evil. This may sound obvious but acknowledging complexity too often gets you tarred as a heinous person.
Seems like you dodged a bullet with the Phillies thing though.

Incredible. Man aren't even willing to put in the basic effort of surreptitiously checking out the title, googling it, and then memorizing several things to say about the author's other work. This is standard stuff man, this like what Hitch would tell you.

value.text: Literally just witnessed a 20ish-year-old man sit down next to a woman reading a book in a coffee shop, get her attention, ask her what she was reading, and then react blankly to the reply before telling her how much he liked 12 Rules for Life by Jordan Peterson

record.text: They’re far too lazy for any of that. A hallmark of how men use the apps is they just like/swipe right on basically everyone and then IF they get a match/response they THEN look at the profile for the first time. See, for example, this exchange I had 5 min ago.

images.alt:
An exchange on Hinge:
Me: A Phillies fan AND you live in Virginia? Hopefully you’re charming because that’s a pretty tough sell…
Him: I’m charming, but I’m not a defund the policy guy, sorry. Not a conservative/republican but you might be too liberal for me.
Me: ok well, you liked my profile first, so 🤷🏼‍♀️

value.text: One of my favorite things about conservative intellectuals is that they never have thoughts about Fyodor Dostoevsky but if you ask them about Gaston or Pumbaa it’s like ok buckle up

(L-R)
1. murder your brother & starve your tribe
2. be vain and jealous of your stepdaughter 
3. look old & ugly when trying to murder your stepdaughter
4. lead a mob to murder your love interest's crush

images.alt: YouTube video titled Matt Walsh Explains Why These Movie Villains Were Right with a thumbnail featuring The Lion King's Scar, The Evil Queen of Snow White in both her natural and "hag" form, and Beauty and the Beast's Gaston.

record.text: Remember the guy on Twitter who was complaining that our woke education system wasn’t teaching boys to grow up to be Odysseus? Like at least Victor Davis Hanson cracked a book or two at some point in his life
